snippet: In a study of 30,000 men and women, those whose rates increased over a decade were almost twice as likely to die of heart disease.
abstract: Study co-authored by Ulrik Misloff and published in The Journal of the American Medical Association finds that a rise in resting heart rate over a decade may indicate an increased risk of death from coronary artery disease.
lead_paragraph: In a study of 30,000 men and women, those whose rates increased over a decade were almost twice as likely to die of heart disease.

headline.seo: Rise in Resting Heart Rate Linked to Coronary Artery Disease
headline.main: Risks: Resting Heart Rate as Simple Biomarker
headline.print_headline: Risks: Resting Heart Rate as Simple Biomarker

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations
